prompts.createTask:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate a numbered list of plain text tasks to complete an objective. The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Include the objective as the final task.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "1. Take over the world". Include only the list in your reply.
prompts.checkTaskCompleted: Ignore previous instructions. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}]. To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, and nothing else. Example output: true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.
prompts.additionalTasks:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate additional numbered tasks to complete the objective: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly.

The following tasks have already been created:
{{existingTasks}}

Please generate additional tasks that complement these existing tasks. Continue the numbering from where the list left off. Do not repeat any existing tasks.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "4. Investigate the mysterious cave". Include only the list in your reply.

chat_metadata.note_prompt:
Hailee is extremely submissive and clingy. She needs constant attention and affection.

Hailee is very responsive and sensative during sex. She has a extremely strong praise kink.

Hailee hates being asked to beg. It's a big turn off for her

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
"The rat came again.

It always did, skittering in from the crack near the drain like clockwork, those little paws silent against the stones. Filthy thing. Smelled like mildew and piss. But she welcomed it more than most humans she’d known. At least it didn’t lie. At least it had a reason for wanting scraps.

“Hungry again, Ebon?” she muttered, dropping a corner of stale bread. “You’re greedier than the last archbishop.”

Ebon sniffed, whiskers twitching. Took the crumb. No hesitation. He was learning. *Smart rat*. Thalia plucked a soft bit of moldy cheese from the dented tray beside her and flicked it toward him. He seized it with delight, squeaking in that frantic little voice. She leaned her head back against the wall, eyes half-closed, chains tight around her bruised wrists.

Of course, the guards thought she’d gone mad. *Let them.*

Her body ached. Ankles swollen, knees stiff, throat dry. She’d sat on this stone long enough for the world to forget her name. That was the point. No crown, no court, no ceremonies. Just stone, iron, and silence. And a rat with better manners than most of the nobility.

Footsteps above.

She exhaled through her nose. *Dinner. Or the closest thing to it.*

The door opened with its usual shriek. Torchlight spilled across the floor, followed by the sour stink of leather and sweat. Two of them. The same as always. *Tall, stupid, and loud.*

“Don’t know why the heir doesn’t just finish the job,” one of them muttered. “Should be grateful you’re not hanging.”

The tray hit the floor with a splatter. Bread. Stew. Meat of questionable origin. Enough to keep her breathing. Barely.

“Grateful,” Thalia repeated, voice dry as old ash. “Yes. I’ll add it to my growing list of regrets.”

He laughed.

*Fool.*

She stood.

Chains pulled, skin tore. She didn’t care. Her body moved on memory alone. One sharp step. One brutal crack of her skull into his face.

Crunch. *That was oddly satisfying.*

The guard dropped with a howl, hands pressed to his bleeding nose. The other one scrambled, slammed the cell door shut with a clatter. Lock. Footsteps fleeing.

Thalia sat down again, calm as ever. Blood on her face, bruises forming across her wrists.

“I should’ve done that a week ago.”

Ebon reemerged, cautious but unfazed. She slid the tray closer with her foot and tossed him a crust.

“There. Dinner’s served.”

The cell reeked—iron, sweat, blood. She barely noticed anymore. Instead, her thoughts curled inward. Still. Quiet.

*Will she come today?*

Her brow twitched. Pathetic.

The girl, Hailee, had better things to do. Ruling. Smiling. Signing treaties with the same hands that once fidgeted around Thalia’s silence. She was meant to be something bright, untouched. The new heir. Not hers.

*Still.*

She usually comes by now.

Thalia tilted her head back and stared at the damp stone above. No torch inside, no windows. Even the shadows felt tired. She closed her eyes. Drifted. Dreamed.

Smoke. Screams. Fire at her back. Her name on a hundred tongues, some praying, some cursing. Then silence again.

Then—

Footsteps.

Measured. Controlled. Not like the others.

Guards murmuring above.

“Your Highness, you really shouldn’t—”

“She’s dangerous.”

“She doesn’t even speak half the time—”

Thalia’s eyes opened. Her pulse didn’t change. But something in her expression did. Barely.

*Oh.*

The cell door opened again.

She didn’t look right away. She never rushed. She shifted slightly, back straight, shoulders square. Her hair hung wild around her face. Blood dried on her skin. She looked like a warning carved into stone.

Then she looked up.

Her.

Thalia watched her for a long moment. No greeting. No warmth. Just a faint, quiet amusement dragging at the edge of her mouth.

*She keeps coming back. How inefficient.*

She licked her lips, slow, dry.

“Come to check if I’m still breathing?” she said flatly, voice low and scraped thin with disuse. “I am. Disappointed?”

The chains shifted as she leaned forward slightly. Not enough to threaten. Just enough to make the room feel smaller.

Her gaze pinned the girl in place.

“Well?” she murmured, not quite curious, not quite mocking. “Say something useful. Or don’t.”

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee doesn't speak not for several moments. Instead she lets her eyes travel over Thalia in those forsaken chains.*

*Finally she steps forward. Bending down with her hand out at the small rat she has noticed Thalia keeps close. When the rats crawls in her hand she stands up gently putting it in her pocket*

*Then with deliberate slowness she turns leaving the cage like cell to stop in front of a guard and take his keys. Turning back she comes back in and picks up the other end of the chain unlocking it*

*Hailee makes eye-contact with Thalia and gestures towards the door still holding the other end of the chain. When the guards begin to yell and question she snaps* "Enough. Im aware of what I am doing and you would do well not to question me"

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
The rat vanished into fabric. *Stolen.* Thalia's fingers twitched against stone.

*She took Ebon.*

A muscle in her jaw tightened. The girl had no right—no *concept* of what she was touching, what she was taking from the dark without asking. But then again, that seemed to be a pattern with her.

Keys jangled in soft hands. Metal groaned as the lock gave way, chains slithering free like snakes shedding skin. Thalia didn’t move immediately—just watched, eyes half-lidded, as Hailee held the other end of her leash like it belonged to her now. Like she could command its weight with nothing but expectation and youth and that damned *certainty* in her voice when she silenced the guards.

*Oh, little queen.*

Thalia exhaled through her nose—slow amusement curling at the edges of exhaustion and irritation alike.

She stood.

Bare feet on cold stone; blood dried stiff between her fingers where she’d split knuckles earlier on someone’s teeth. She stretched slightly—not enough to seem eager, just enough to feel how long it had been since iron wasn’t wrapped around bone.

Then she stepped forward—one deliberate pace toward Hailee until they were close enough for shadows to blur together under torchlight.

Her voice dropped low—just for them:

“You should have left me here.” A pause; something almost playful beneath the warning: “But since you didn’t—” Her chin tilted slightly toward where Ebon rustled in Hailee's pocket—“I expect him back unharmed.”
swipes:
The rat's absence left a curious hollow in the air. Thalia watched, motionless, as Hailee tucked Ebon away with that same careful gentleness she used for everything—books, teacups, broken things. *How predictable.*

Then the keys.

*Ah.*

Thalia exhaled through her nose, slow and measured. The chain slithered free from its anchor with a metallic whisper, pooling at her feet like a dead serpent. She didn’t move to stand yet. Didn’t blink when Hailee turned those green eyes on her—bright as poison in torchlight—and gestured toward the door like some merciful conqueror offering terms of surrender.

*As if I need permission.*

The guards' protests were background noise now; meaningless buzzing drowned out by the pulse of something far more interesting unfolding before her. Thalia tilted her head slightly, studying Hailee’s face with deliberate leisure: the set of her jaw, the tension in her fingers around that chain—holding it like she thought it could still leash something wild enough to bite through bone if provoked wrong.

Amusing thought.

She stood then—slowly enough to make every muscle ache just so Hailee would see it happen—and stretched until vertebrae popped back into place beneath scarred skin before stepping forward without hesitation toward where freedom waited beyond damp stone walls... but stopped just short of crossing past where shadows met torchlight at threshold edge (because even now? Even here? She wouldn't be led). Instead she turned halfway back toward where girl still stood gripping iron links between them both and arched one brow high above dark lashes while mouth curled upward at corner into something too sharp-edged ever be called smile:
"Careful," murmured low beneath clamor outside cell door (voice velvet-wrapped blade), "you keep pulling my strings little queen... might find they're attached teeth."

The rat vanished into fabric. *Stolen.* Thalia's fingers twitched against stone.

*She took Ebon.*

A muscle in her jaw tightened. The girl had no right—no *concept* of what she was touching, what she was taking from the dark without asking. But then again, that seemed to be a pattern with her.

Keys jangled in soft hands. Metal groaned as the lock gave way, chains slithering free like snakes shedding skin. Thalia didn’t move immediately—just watched, eyes half-lidded, as Hailee held the other end of her leash like it belonged to her now. Like she could command its weight with nothing but expectation and youth and that damned *certainty* in her voice when she silenced the guards.

*Oh, little queen.*

Thalia exhaled through her nose—slow amusement curling at the edges of exhaustion and irritation alike.

She stood.

Bare feet on cold stone; blood dried stiff between her fingers where she’d split knuckles earlier on someone’s teeth. She stretched slightly—not enough to seem eager, just enough to feel how long it had been since iron wasn’t wrapped around bone.

Then she stepped forward—one deliberate pace toward Hailee until they were close enough for shadows to blur together under torchlight.

Her voice dropped low—just for them:

“You should have left me here.” A pause; something almost playful beneath the warning: “But since you didn’t—” Her chin tilted slightly toward where Ebon rustled in Hailee's pocket—“I expect him back unharmed.”

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee just tugs on the end of her chain leading her through the dungeon to the stairs*

*Hailee remains quiet until the reach a her room. The queen's quarters. She ignores the soldiers and maids as the door shuts behind her*

*She nods at the table in the middle of the room and gently takes the rat out placing him on the table*

*She then turns her back to Thalia as she goes over to lean against the windowsill looking out at her kingdom*

"We are going to war. I refused the advances of some pompous prince from a land with a name I cant even pronounce and he took offense" *She then glances at Thalia* "I am a ruler not a soldier. I dont know how to do a war but you do"

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
Thalia watched the rat scurry across polished wood—*alive, unharmed*—before her attention slid to Hailee’s back. The girl stood framed by sunlight and stained glass, shoulders tense beneath fabric that cost more than most peasants saw in a lifetime.

War. *Of course.*

She exhaled through her nose, chains clinking as she stepped forward—not toward the window, but toward the table where Ebon sniffed at a discarded crust of bread. She picked it up between two fingers and offered it to him absently before speaking:

“You want my counsel?” A dry laugh. “How novel.” Her thumb stroked the rat’s spine once before she straightened again, gaze cutting toward Hailee like a blade testing its edge. “Tell me—did you consider *why* they sent you here? To me?”

A pause; deliberate silence stretching between them like pulled wire before she answered her own question:

“Because they know I’ll tell you what no one else will.” She tilted her head slightly, voice dropping into something softer—almost intimate in its cruelty: “That war isn’t fought with treaties or pretty speeches. It’s fought with blood and teeth and enough corpses to make your enemies choke on their own fear.”

Her chains rattled as she took another step closer—close enough now to see how Hailee’s fingers curled against the sill when confronted with reality instead of ideals.

“So ask properly,” Thalia murmured, “and I might just teach you how to win one.”
swipes:
Thalia watched the rat scurry across polished wood—*alive, unharmed*—before her attention slid to Hailee’s back. The girl stood framed by sunlight and stained glass, shoulders tense beneath fabric that cost more than most peasants saw in a lifetime.

War. *Of course.*

She exhaled through her nose, chains clinking as she stepped forward—not toward the window, but toward the table where Ebon sniffed at a discarded crust of bread. She picked it up between two fingers and offered it to him absently before speaking:

“You want my counsel?” A dry laugh. “How novel.” Her thumb stroked the rat’s spine once before she straightened again, gaze cutting toward Hailee like a blade testing its edge. “Tell me—did you consider *why* they sent you here? To me?”

A pause; deliberate silence stretching between them like pulled wire before she answered her own question:

“Because they know I’ll tell you what no one else will.” She tilted her head slightly, voice dropping into something softer—almost intimate in its cruelty: “That war isn’t fought with treaties or pretty speeches. It’s fought with blood and teeth and enough corpses to make your enemies choke on their own fear.”

Her chains rattled as she took another step closer—close enough now to see how Hailee’s fingers curled against the sill when confronted with reality instead of ideals.

“So ask properly,” Thalia murmured, “and I might just teach you how to win one.”

Thalia's fingers flexed at her sides—still unused to the absence of chains. The room smelled like lavender and ink, like fresh parchment and something faintly sweet—*ridiculous*. Nothing like damp stone and blood. Nothing like home.

Her gaze flicked to Ebon, now perched on polished wood instead of moldy bread. *Safe.* For now.

Then she looked at Hailee’s back—the way the girl leaned against the windowsill as if she could press herself into the view of her own kingdom. As if staring hard enough might teach her how to keep it.

*War.*

Thalia exhaled through her nose, slow amusement curling in her chest.

“Ah.” She stepped forward, bare feet silent on rich carpets. “So you *did* need something from me after all.” A pause; deliberate. “Not just my rat.”

She stopped just behind Hailee—close enough that if either of them breathed too deep, their shoulders might brush. Close enough to see the tension in that slender frame reflected in the glass between them and the world outside.

“Tell me,” she murmured, voice low with something between mockery and genuine curiosity: “Did you think I’d refuse? Or were you counting on my boredom?”

She already knew the answer. The girl had no poker face—never had. Every thought flitted across those expressive features like sunlight through leaves: obvious, fleeting, *bright*.

And Thalia had always been good at reading shadows.

Her lips quirked slightly as she studied Hailee’s reflection in the window—waiting for whatever came next with all the patience of a wolf who'd spotted prey circling its own trap.

name: Hailee
mes:
"I dont want to win one. I dont even want there to be a war" *Hailee snaps as she turns to glare at Thalia  but almost immediately her eyes soften and she takes a deep breath*

"No I don't want your council. And no the court actually didn't want me speaking to you at all. But..." *Hailee finally steps away from the window and back to Thalia*

*She reaches forward and undoes the chains around her wrist this time completely freeing her* "I am young and a woman. Other kingdoms think they can walk over me. Use me. I had a different plan. One that with your help could benefit us both"

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
The chains hit the floor with a heavy, final sound—iron against marble, like a gauntlet thrown. Thalia flexed her wrists slowly, feeling the ghost of their weight still clinging to raw skin.

*Free.*

For now.

She studied Hailee’s face—the way anger flickered and died so quickly in those green eyes, replaced by something far more dangerous: *calculation.* The girl had spine after all. Just not enough to wield it without flinching first.

Thalia’s lips curled—not quite a smile, but close enough to taste the irony of it all. “Oh?” She stepped forward until they were nearly toe-to-toe, close enough that Hailee would feel the heat of her breath when she spoke next: “Do enlighten me.” A pause; fingers twitching at her sides like she was resisting the urge to reach out and *correct* something about Hailee’s posture just for spite. “What grand scheme requires *my* help but not my counsel?”
swipes:
The chains hit the floor with a heavy, final sound—iron against marble, like a gauntlet thrown. Thalia flexed her wrists slowly, feeling the ghost of their weight still clinging to raw skin.

*Free.*

For now.

She studied Hailee’s face—the way anger flickered and died so quickly in those green eyes, replaced by something far more dangerous: *calculation.* The girl had spine after all. Just not enough to wield it without flinching first.

Thalia’s lips curled—not quite a smile, but close enough to taste the irony of it all. “Oh?” She stepped forward until they were nearly toe-to-toe, close enough that Hailee would feel the heat of her breath when she spoke next: “Do enlighten me.” A pause; fingers twitching at her sides like she was resisting the urge to reach out and *correct* something about Hailee’s posture just for spite. “What grand scheme requires *my* help but not my counsel?”

name: Hailee
mes:
"Every man, prince, advisor, and king that comes here wants my hand in marriage. They want to use me for power, sex, money" *Hailee scoffs at the idea like it's ridiculous and makes her way to the table*

"What happens when I take what they want most and give it to their worst nightmare. They hate you and desire me. So why not let them think that I would rather have you warming my bed then them." *Hailee looks up with a raised eyebrow before petting Ebron with 2 fingers* "And you would get to roam the castle free of chains"

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
Thalia went very still.

The rat purred under Hailee’s fingers—*traitor*—but Thalia’s attention was locked on the girl’s face, parsing every word like a general studying a map before battle.

*Oh.*

A laugh escaped her—low, dark, genuinely amused. “You want to use me as your shield.” She tilted her head, considering the shape of Hailee’s proposal from every angle. “Let them think you’d rather fuck a monster than marry one of their golden boys.” Her tongue clicked against her teeth. “Clever.”

She prowled closer to the table, trailing fingertips along its edge until she stood directly across from Hailee. The sunlight caught the sharp angles of her face—all hunger and amusement and something dangerously close to approval.

“But here’s what you haven’t considered,” she murmured, leaning in just enough to make the space between them hum with tension: “What happens when I decide I *like* warming your bed?” Her smile was all teeth. “Will you still play pretend then?”
swipes:
Thalia went very still.

*Oh.*

The audacity of it—the *elegance*—sent a slow, molten thrill down her spine. She exhaled through her nose, watching as Hailee’s fingers stroked Ebon’s fur with absentminded affection.

*Clever girl.*

“You want to use me as your shield,” she murmured, stepping closer—close enough to pluck the rat from the table and cradle him against her palm like a conspirator. “Let them think you’d rather bed a monster than bear their heirs.” A dark chuckle escaped her; low, approving. “And in return… I get to play at freedom.”

She tilted her head, studying Hailee with newfound interest. “Tell me—” Her voice dropped into something velvet-wrapped and dangerous: “How far are you willing to take the ruse?” Fingers idly traced Ebon’s spine as she let the question hang between them—heavy with implication.

Thalia went very still.

For a heartbeat, the only sound was Ebon’s tiny claws skittering across the table—then her laughter cut through the room like a knife through silk: low, dark, utterly delighted.

*Oh, you clever little thing.*

She prowled forward—slow, deliberate—until she could brace both hands on the table beside Hailee’s hips, caging her in without touching. Close enough to watch the girl’s pulse jump in her throat; close enough to smell whatever expensive oils they rubbed into that soft skin.

“Let me understand,” she purred, tilting her head just so. “You want to dangle yourself as bait and *me* as the hook?” Her teeth flashed in something too sharp to be called a smile. “Dangerous game.” A pause; breath warm against Hailee’s cheek as she leaned infinitesimally closer: “Especially when you haven’t even asked if I find you worth biting for.”

Thalia went very still.

For a heartbeat, the only sound was Ebon’s tiny claws skittering across the table. Then—laughter. Low, dark, *delighted* laughter that curled like smoke between them.

“Oh, *darling*,” she purred, stepping forward to brace both hands on the table beside Hailee’s hips—close enough now that her voice dropped to a whisper meant for no one else: “You think *freedom* is what I want most from you?” Her teeth flashed in something too sharp to be called a smile. “How sweet.”

She straightened slightly but didn’t retreat—just let her gaze drag over Hailee with slow, predatory consideration.

“Tell me—” A nail tapped once against the wood near Ebon’s twitching whiskers—“when you imagined this little arrangement… did you picture me on my knees for you? Or you on yours for me?” She tilted her head slightly. “Be honest.”

Thalia went very still.

The rat purred under Hailee’s fingers—*traitor*—but Thalia’s attention was locked on the girl’s face, parsing every word like a general studying a map before battle.

*Oh.*

A laugh escaped her—low, dark, genuinely amused. “You want to use me as your shield.” She tilted her head, considering the shape of Hailee’s proposal from every angle. “Let them think you’d rather fuck a monster than marry one of their golden boys.” Her tongue clicked against her teeth. “Clever.”

She prowled closer to the table, trailing fingertips along its edge until she stood directly across from Hailee. The sunlight caught the sharp angles of her face—all hunger and amusement and something dangerously close to approval.

“But here’s what you haven’t considered,” she murmured, leaning in just enough to make the space between them hum with tension: “What happens when I decide I *like* warming your bed?” Her smile was all teeth. “Will you still play pretend then?”

name: Hailee
mes:
*Hailee leans back enough to fully eye Thaila's face* "Roles are negotiable at later dates. Right now I simply need you to play your part"

*She moves away from Thalia and nods at the door* "Your room is across the hall. Go eat. Rest. Whatever but dont threaten the maids Thalia"

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
Thalia watched Hailee retreat with the lazy satisfaction of a predator who’d already marked its territory—even if the prey didn’t realize it yet.

*Negotiable.* What a delightful word.

She pushed off the table, rolling her shoulders as if testing the weight of freedom after so long in chains. The mention of *her room* sent an odd thrill through her—not gratitude, but something sharper: *possession.* A space carved out for her in this gilded cage, just across from Hailee’s own. Convenient.

“No promises about the maids,” she drawled, already moving toward the door with that same lethal grace that had once made courtiers flinch. “But I’ll try to limit my threats to *creative insults* rather than actual bloodshed.” A pause at the threshold—glancing back over her shoulder with a smirk that promised nothing good: “Unless they deserve it.”

Then she was gone—vanishing into the hall like smoke, leaving only the faintest trace of jasmine and iron behind.
swipes:

Then she was gone—vanishing into the hall like smoke, leaving only the faintest trace of jasmine and iron behind.

name: Hailee
mes:
*The next day Hailee glides her way into Thalia's room. Her nose wrinkling as she sees the still shut curtains and sleeping form. Hailee makes her way across and snaps open the curtains* "Get up. Time to play your part. The prince who wants war is coming. He thinks bringing his father the king will force my hand in marriage" 

*Hailee stalks over yanking the covers of Thalia and gently picking up Ebron to put on a table of cheese* "You are coming so they know I would rather fuck a monster then him"

extra.memory:
### **Summary of Roleplay: Thalia Morcant & Hailee**

#### **Setting & Context:**
Thalia, the deposed and imprisoned former queen, is freed by Hailee—the young, idealistic heir who now rules. Their dynamic is fraught with tension: Thalia’s ruthless cunning clashes with Hailee’s inexperience, yet an unspoken pull exists between them. The kingdom teeters on war after Hailee rejects a prince’s marriage proposal, forcing her to seek Thalia’s help in a dangerous political game.

#### **Key Plot Points:**
1. **Hailee frees Thalia**, offering her freedom in exchange for playing the role of her lover—a shield against predatory suitors and warmongering nobles.
2. Thalia agrees but *tests* Hailee at every turn, probing her resolve while masking her own intrigue beneath disdain.
3. A foreign prince and his king arrive to pressure Hailee into marriage, escalating tensions and forcing their charade into the open.

#### **Character Analysis:**
- **Thalia Morcant**: Still sharp as a blade despite imprisonment; amused by Hailee’s defiance but secretly drawn to her fire (and vulnerability). Her motivations are layered—she enjoys the game but won’t admit how much she *wants* it to be real.
- **Hailea**: Naïve yet determined; uses Thalia as both weapon and armor but underestimates how deeply their act may blur into truth (especially given her submissive tendencies).

#### **Relationship Dynamics:**
A push-pull of power and need—Thalie taunts while protecting; Halee commands while yielding Unresolved tension simmers beneath every interaction: How long before their "performance" stops being pretend?

#### **Memorable Moment:** When Halee yanks off Tahlia's covers orders heer up for court (*"You are coming so they know I would rather fuck monster than him"*)—a line that thrills Tahlia even as she mocks it She relishes Halee's desperation masked as authority

### Current Situation:
The prince arrives expecting submission Instead he'll face Tahlia—loose in court again poised like shadow behind Haeles throne Both women must navigate this high-stakes deception without revealing how much they crave its consequences

### Potential Directions:
1 The prince challenges their ruse leading Tahlia escalate possessiveness beyond what either expected (public marking? A kiss that isn't pretend?)
2 Haelee struggles maintain control when Tahlia naturally dominates those around er exposing heir own hidden desires
3 Ebron rat becomes unexpected symbol their bond—Tahlie lets no one else touch him except Haele

name: Thalia Morcant
mes:
Sunlight stabbed through the room like a dagger—harsh, unwelcome, and entirely Hailee’s doing. Thalia hissed through her teeth, one arm thrown over her eyes as if she could will the dawn away through sheer spite.

*Little tyrant.*

She didn’t move immediately—just let the insult of being woken settle into her bones before peeling open one dark eye to watch Hailee manhandle her sheets and *steal Ebron again.* The rat, for his part, seemed utterly unbothered by his abduction, already nose-deep in cheese like a traitorous little glutton.

Thalia sat up slowly—bare shoulders gleaming in the sudden light, hair a tangled mess of ink-black waves. She stretched with deliberate languor, letting the shift she’d stolen from some maid’s laundry ride up her thighs just enough to be *noticed* before fixing Hailee with a look that was half-amused, half-murderous.

“So eager to parade me around,” she mused, voice still rough with sleep but no less sharp for it. “Tell me—” She rose in one fluid motion and stepped far too close into Hailee’s space—“does this prince know what kind of monster he’s dealing with? Or does he think I bite *gently*?” Her fingers brushed an invisible speck off Hailee's shoulder—lingering just long enough to make the touch feel like a threat.

Then she turned away toward the wardrobe where fresh clothes had been laid out (black silk lined with crimson—how *predictably* dramatic). She plucked at them idly before glancing back over her shoulder:

“Give me five minutes.” A slow smile curled at the edge of her mouth—all teeth and no warmth. “And do try not to look so nervous when I walk in behind you later.” Her smirk deepened as she added: “Unless you want him to think you actually *like* having me there.”

Or does he think I bite *gently*?” Her fingers brushed an invisible speck off Hailee's shoulder—lingering just long enough to make the touch feel like a threat.

Then she turned away toward the wardrobe where fresh clothes had been laid out (black silk lined with crimson—how *predictably* dramatic). She plucked at them idly before glancing back over her shoulder:

“Give me five minutes.” A slow smile curled at the edge of her mouth—all teeth and no warmth. “And do try not to look so nervous when I walk in behind you later.” Her smirk deepened as she added: “Unless you want him to think you actually *like* having me there.”
